PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The government has conducted some technical studies that have been prepared for the 
proposed  subprojects  using  the  government’s  and  development  partners’  funds.  A  project 
preparatory technical assistance (TA) is needed to review these plans and studies and develop 
a project suitable for Asian Development Bank (ADB) funding in terms of technical, financial, 
economic, institutional, sector policy, legal, and safeguard contexts, in conjunction with the 
ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  (CPS),  operational  experience,  and  lessons  from 
evaluations of previous projects. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The  project  preparatory  TA  will  (i)  conduct  sector  and  subsector  analysis;  (ii)  help 
prioritize  and  identify  project  components  for  the  ensuing  loan  project;  (iii)  determine  the 
feasibility of the proposed investments for priority infrastructure construction and improvements 
covering (a) preliminary engineering designs, (b) cost estimates and financing plan, (c) financial 
and economic viability  and sustainability, (d) environmental and social soundness, and (e) 
detailed implementation arrangements; and (iv) prepare an institutional capacity strengthening 
and public awareness programs. The TA will also prepare the project administration manual 
(PAM) that includes all the information and schedules describing project implementation. The 
TA will follow the government’s Decision 48/2008/QD-ttg on Common General Guidelines on 
Feasibility  study  Preparation  for  Official  Development  Assistance  Projects  Funded  by  Five 
Banks issued on 4 March 2008. The major outputs and activities of the TA are summarized in

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  A team of consultants will be engaged through firm(s). The TA will require 9 positions 
and 23 person-months (pm) of international and 13 positions and 43 pm of national consulting 
services. ADB will select and engage consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The quality- and cost-based selection 
method with quality-cost ratio of 80:20, using full technical proposal procedures, will be followed. 
A small number of national individual consultants will be additionally engaged after submission 
of the draft final report, to support start-up activities of the ensuing loan project on an as-needed 
basis using the contingencies.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the consultants are described in Table A4.4 
 
Table A4.4: Outline Terms of Reference 
Sector and subsector analysis. The consultant will (i) review existing urban sector and subsector 
master plans, regulations, reports, standards, and studies; (ii) assess climate change impacts; (iii) predict 
the future development needs and trends; (iv) assess the existing institutional framework for urban 
planning, development, and management; and (v) prepare climate change resilient urban and land use 
plans which guide the future urban growth. 
Technical aspects. The consultant will (i) review subsector development strategies, natural environment, 
existing infrastructure conditions, and institutional framework; (ii) consult key stakeholders to identify 
major issues and bottlenecks; (iii) confirm the priority areas and finalize the infrastructure investment 
subprojects; (iv) collect and analyze information on infrastructure and civil works; (v) analyze design 
alternatives and identify the most suitable design; (vi) introduce climate resilient designs for infrastructure 
facilities; (vii) prepare preliminary engineering design and cost estimates; (viii) prepare an operation and 
maintenance plan; (ix) prepare a pilot recycling of wastewater and sludge; (x) conduct the procurement 
capacity assessment; (xi) prepare a procurement plan; and (xii) prepare the PAM. 
Economic analysis. The consultant will (i) conduct socioeconomic surveys and prepare baseline data; 
(ii) conduct SWOT analysis; (iii) refine the project rationale; and (iv) prepare economic analyses for 
individual project components as well as the project as a whole following ADB’s guidelines. 
Financial analysis. The consultant will (i) conduct financial management assessments and recommend 
measures to strengthen financial management capacities; (ii) prepare a project financing plan, and design 
the funds flow and disbursement mechanism; (iii) propose auditor arrangements; (iv) prepare financial 
analyses for wastewater and solid waste management subprojects; (vi) forecast the incremental recurrent 
costs to ascertain the long-term impact of the project; (vii) address and propose a business model for the 
components  which  have  the  potential  to  be  revenue-generating;  and  (viii)  conduct  affordability 
assessment including willingness to pay. 
Environment. The consultant will (i) collect data on environmental conditions; (ii) conduct environment 
screening and assess the environment category of the project; (iii) assess the projected impacts of 
climate change on the project areas and proposed investments in 2020, 2030, and 2050; (iv) assess the 
environmental  impacts  of  the  infrastructure  works;  (v)  ensure  close  integration  of  environment 
sustainability and climate resilient in infrastructure designs; (vi) conduct an environment compliance audit 
for existing facilities which will be rehabilitated under the project; and (vii) prepare an environmental 
impact assessment for each subproject in accordance with ADB’s safeguard policy statement. 
Social safeguard. The consultant will (i) assess the significance of the land acquisition and resettlement 
impacts, and prepare resettlement plans (RPs) accordingly; (ii) help the government initiate a participatory

process  for  RP  preparation;  (iii)  conduct  public  consultations;  and  (iv)  assess  the  capacity  of  the 
responsible institutions to plan, update, and implement RPs, and propose training programs. 
Institutional analysis and capacity strengthening. The consultant will (i) identify policy, institutional, 
regulatory, and human resource bottlenecks for wastewater management and flood control; (ii) assess 
the  managerial,  technical,  financial,  and  administrative  capacities;  (iii)  prepare  realistic  project 
implementation arrangements; (iv) review existing training programs; (v) prepare an institutional analyses; 
and (vi) develop capacity development programs for local government agencies. 
Social analysis. The consultant will (i) help conduct socioeconomic surveys; (ii) review the government 
policies and strategies for poverty reduction and gender development; (iii) conduct a public perception 
survey to identify public problems and development priorities; (iv) conduct a poverty and social analysis, 
(v) prepare a poverty and social strategy; (vi) collect sex-disaggregated data for possible gender targets 
used in the project; (vii) develop gender targets in the design and monitoring framework; (viii) prepare a 
gender action plan; (ix) prepare a participatory strategy; (x) assess potential impacts on indigenous 
peoples  and  prepare  a  stakeholder  communication  strategy;  and  (xi)  develop  public  health  and 
environmental protection awareness programs. 
PAM = project administration manual; SWOT = strengths, weakness, opportunities, and threats. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The provincial people’s committees (PPCs) of Quang Binh, Quang Nam, and Thanh Hoa 
will be the executing agencies for the TA. Project management units will be established under 
the Quang Binh provincial urban environment company (URENCO), Quang Nam provincial 
water supply joint stock company, and Sam Son town people’s committee to undertake day-to-
day TA activities. Quang Binh PPC will be the lead coordinators to liaise with the project cities 
and the concerned central government agencies when needed. The government will provide (i) 
all  relevant  documents,  data,  statistics,  reports,  and  maps;  (ii)  qualified  counterpart  staff, 
including their field per diem and field transportation; (iii) office accommodation and office 
equipment, including desks, chairs, and local communication; and (iv) logistic assistance for the 
workshops and seminars, including venue provision and identifying and sending invitations to 
participants. 
 
17.  Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, amended from time to time). The consultants 
may  procure  equipment  through  shopping  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, amended from time to time). Upon completion of the TA, equipment procured 
under the TA will be transferred to the executing agencies.
